questions.solution:
Correct answer is c: Cabot rings; Dyserythropoiesis

questions.text: All of the following are complications of sickle cell disease except?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is d: Neonatal Jaundice

Neonatal jaundice is not a feature of sickle cell anemia because in newborns, HbF predominates and prevents sickling. Hemolysis is minimal until HbF levels drop over months.

Sticky red blood cells cause stroke, pulmonary vaso-occlusion causing PAG and vitreous hemorrhage and retinal detachment.

questions.text: A 15-year-old male with sickle cell anemia presents with hematuria and flank pain. Urinalysis shows isosthenuria (urine specific gravity ~1.010). Which of the following is the most likely explanation?

choices.text: Glomerulonephritis due to immune complex deposition
Recurrent urinary tract infection causing tubular damage

questions.solution:
Correct answer is a: Medullary infarction causing papillary necrosis

Renal medulla is particularly prone to hypoxia due to its low oxygen tension and hyperosmolar environment. Sickled RBC are very sticky and cause microinfarctions.

This leads to papillary necrosis, which causes hematuria and isosthenuria (inability to concentrate urine).

questions.text: For prenatal diagnosis of sickle cell anemia which is the best test?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is c: DNA Analysis

DNA analysis (via CVS at 10–12 weeks or amniocentesis at 15–18 weeks) detects the specific HBB gene point mutation.

NESTROFT and sickling tests are screening tools for carriers, not used on fetal samples.

Hb electrophoresis cannot reliably diagnose sickle cell in early gestation because fetal Hb (HbF) predominates.

questions.text: Heinz bodies in G6PD deficiency is?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is a: Denatured Hemoglobin

Inclusion body

Composition

Classic cause

Heinz bodies

G6PD deficiency, unstable Hb

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria

choices.text: Sucrose hemolysis test is gold standard
Hypocellular bone marrow that becomes hypercellular in late stages

questions.solution:
Correct answer is c: Thrombosis of hepatic veins

PNH occurs due to defects of PIGA gene and has CD55 and CD59 negativity. This makes Red blood cells susceptible to complement mediated destruction and results in intravascular hemolysis. Sucrose hemolysis is an outdated test and flow cytometry helps in diagnosis. Due to RBC loss initially hypercellular marrow is seen with erythroid hyperplasia. Later hypocellular marrow or aplastic status may be seen.

PNH core aspects

  1. Poor quality RBC that undergo complement mediated destruction: Black color urine and low Hb
  2. Poor quality WBC: so infections and low NAP score
  3. Poor quality Platelets that so spontaneous aggregation: Budd chiari syndrome, cerebral venous thrombosis.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the clinic with multiple petechiae over his lower limbs and mild gum bleeding for 2 days. He had an upper respiratory infection about 3 weeks ago. Examination shows scattered ecchymoses and petechial rash but no hepatosplenomegaly or lymphadenopathy. CBC reveals: Hemoglobin: 12.4 g/dL, Total leukocyte count: 8,500/mm³ and Platelet count: 35,000/mm³ Peripheral smear confirms thrombocytopenia with normal RBC and WBC morphology. Coagulation profile is normal. What is the most likely diagnosis and next step in management?

choices.text: Acute lymphoblastic leukemia; bone marrow biopsy

questions.solution:
Correct answer is b: Acute immune thrombocytopenic purpura: observation

Acute ITP is common in children, often post-viral, with isolated thrombocytopenia, no systemic toxicity, no organomegaly, and normal other cell lines.

Most children recover spontaneously and observation only unless there is severe bleeding or platelets <10,000/μL.

Bone marrow exam is not required unless atypical features are present (e.g., organomegaly, anemia, leukopenia).

questions.text: A patient with acute kidney injury is found to have hemolytic uraemic syndrome. Which of the following is not correct about this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is D: Antibodies to ADAMTS13

Antibodies to ADAMTS13 will cause TTP. HUS has shiga toxin induced microthrombi in kidney circulation causing renal shut down with MAHA and schistocytes.

Classic pentad (TTP)
  1. MAHA (microangiopathic hemolytic anemia →schistocytes)
  2. Thrombocytopenia
  3. Neurologic symptoms
  4. Renal dysfunction (mild – moderate)
  5. Fever

Triad (HUS):

  1. MAHA (Schistocytes)
  2. Thrombocytopenia
  3. Severe acute renal failure

Labs

Schistocytes on smear – 1. LDH, Indirect bilirubin – normal coagulation profile (PT, aPTT normal)

Same as TTP ( schistocytes, MAHA, thrombocytopenia ) but renal failure more prominent

Triggers

Autoimmune disease, drugs (clopidogrel, cyclosporine, quinine), pregnancy, HIV

Bloody diarrhea from E. coli O157: H&, shigella dysenteria

Treatment

Plasma exchange (plasmapheresis) + steroids; avoid platelet transfusion

Mainly supportive (hydration, dialysis if needed); avoid antibiotics & antimotility agents in E.coli O157:H7 diarrhea

questions.text: A 45 year old diabetic with HbA1c of 10% is detected with a low EGFR of 10 has come for hemodialysis session. His Hb= 6gm% with normocytic normochromic anemia. Which of the following is first line treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is a: Oral Iron

This patient of CKD is undergoing hemodialysis. Blood loss that occurs during dialysis procedure leads to iron deficiency. Iron must be replenished before starting ESA agents.

Roxadustat is a hypoxia-inducible factor prolyl hydroxylase inhibitor (HIF-PHI) and is a newer oral drug for anemia in CKD.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about anemia of chronic disease?

choices.text: Low serum iron, elevated serum ferritin, low erythropoietin
Low serum iron, low serum ferritin, low erythropoietin
High serum iron, low serum ferritin, low erythropoietin
High serum iron, elevated serum ferritin, low erythropoietin

questions.solution:
Correct answer is a: Low serum iron, elevated serum ferritin, low erythropoietin

In anemia of chronic disease also called anemia of inflammation, the key lab pattern is-

  1. Serum iron is low as iron trapped in macrophages due to increased levels of hepcidin
  2. Ferritin is elevated as the stores are not utilized
  3. Erythropoietin is low due to blunted marrow stimulation

questions.text: Leading cause of Perinicious anemia?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is B: Autoimmune gastritis

  • Parietal cell antibody is present in 90% of adult patients with PA and is directed against the α and β subunits of the gastric proton pump (H+, K+-ATPase).This causes deficiency of intrinsic factor and resultant B12 deficiency.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about hand and foot syndrome seen in sickle cell anemia?

choices.text: Usually seen after 5 year of age
Infection with capsulated organisms causing osteomyelitis of small bones of hands
X-ray-shows periostitis and soft tissue swelling

questions.solution:
Correct answer is d: X-ray shows periostitis and soft tissue swelling

Dactylitis / Hand and foot syndrome seen in sickle cell anemia causes avascular necrosis of bone marrow and cortical bone leading to radiological findings of periostitis and soft tissue swellings

It is not seen after 5 years as hematopoiesis shifts out of bone marrow after 5 years. it does not cause joint deformities as the articular surface is not involved.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about sickle cell anaemia?

choices.text: Beta 7 valine residues cause polymerization of HbS on deoxygenation
Beta 7 valine residues cause polymerization of HbS on oxygenation
Beta 6 glutamate residues cause polymerization of HbS on oxygenation
Beta 6 glutamate residues cause polymerization of HbS on deoxygenation

questions.solution:
Correct answer is a: Beta 7 valine residues cause polymerization of HbS on deoxygenation

  • HbS has replacement of glutamate from valine at beta 7 that causes polymerization of HbS on deoxygenation. This causes initially reversible deformation of RBC / Sickling episodes. Later the RBC before irreversibly deformed.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct report seen in sickle cell anemia?

choices.text: HbA absent , Hb S present, Hb F elevated, Hb A2 elevated
HbA present ,Hb S present, Hb F elevated, Hb A2 elevated
HbA present ,Hb S present , Hb F elevated, Hb A2 elevated
HbA absent , Hb S present, Hb F reduced , Hb A2 elevated

questions.solution:
Correct answer is a: HbA absent, Hb S present, Hb F elevated, Hb A2 elevated

In homozygous sickle cell anemia (HbSS), the hemoglobin electrophoresis report typically shows:

  • HbA : Absent (no normal β chains are produced)
  • HbS : Present (predominant)
  • HbF : Elevated (protective effect, especially in children)
  • HbA₂ : Slightly elevated (can be mildly increased due to compensatory δ chain production)

questions.text: A 15 year old patient presents with anemia with splenomegaly. P. Smear is shown below. Comment on the Peripheral smear shown below
questions.solution:
Correct answer id d: Pyropokilocytosis

The image shows marked poikilocytosis with microspherocytes, schistocytes, and elliptocytes. Looks similar to smear in severe burns.

Pyropoikilocytosis is a rare form of hereditary elliptocytosis characterized by extreme red blood cell shape abnormalities and marked thermal sensitivity of the RBC membrane. It is autosomal recessive and occurs when a person inherits two abnormal spectrin alleles.

questions.text: A 5 year child born to consanguineous marriage is brought with complaints of pain in both hands over the metacarpals. Work up shows low Hb with increased reticulocyte count, increased LDH and low haptoglobin levels. Spleen is not palpable. Hb electrophoresis report is awaited. He has had previous hospitalizations for acute abdomen. Diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is a: Sickle cell anemia

Key words are family history of consanguinity, lab evidence of hemolysis and clinical pointers lead to sickle cell anemia.

Sickled RBC becomes sticky and causes vaso-occlusive crisis. This explains pain in small bones of the hands and abdominal crisis. Most patients will develop autosplenectomy by 3 years of age.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs can be used in patients with G6PD?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is b: Artensunate

Drugs That Carry Risk of Clinical Hemolysis in Persons with Glucose 6-Phosphate Dehydrogenase Deficiency

 

DEFINITE RISK

Antimalarials

Primaquine, Dapsone/chlorproguanil

Sulphonamides/sulphones

Dapsone

Antibacterial/antibiotics

Cotrimoxazole, Nalidixic acid , Nitrofurantoin, Niridazole

Antipyretic/analgesics

Acetanilide, Phenazopyridine

Other

Rasburicase, Naphthalene, Methylene blue

questions.text: Peripheral smear of a neonate with jaundice shows normocytic normochromic anemia with anisocytosis and poikilocytosis with RBC showing unevenly distributed hemoglobin “ hemighosts” or “blister cells”. This is seen in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is c: G6PD

The findings given here are of bite cells containing denatured hemoglobin. The oxidative stress is damaging hemoglobin in absence of glucose 6 phosphate dehydrogenase. The clinical hint is of neonatal jaundice.

G6PD deficiency can present in premature babies with infection or environmental risk factors like naphthalene camphor balls that may be used in babies bedding and clothing.

Option A will produce RBC with asymmetrically placed spikes on the surface called acanthocytes. Option B will cause schistocytes. Option C will produce RBC with equidistant spikes called echinocytes

Symmetrically placed spikes on RBC

Echinocytes

Asymmetrically placed spikes on RBC

Acanthocytes

questions.text: A 5 year old child is brought with complaints of pain in hands. On examination he has severe pallor, elevated LDH and low haptoglobin. The HPLC report is shown below. Which of the following is the drug of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is A: Hydroxyurea

  • The clinical diagnosis is sickle cell anemia and hydroxyurea is the drug of choice for patients of all ages regardless of symptom profile. The major mechanism of action of hydroxyurea is to induce high levels of HbF so that cells have greater protection from HbS polymerization than others. Voxeltor has recently been recalled. Option B is used in MDS and Option D is used in multiple myeloma.

questions.text: Which of the following treatments is curative in sickle cell anemia?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is b: Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation

Allogeneic HSCT from an HLA-identical sibling donor is the only established curative therapy for sickle cell disease.

Hydroxyurea increases HbF and reduces episodes of sickling crisis. Voxelotor is a HbS polymerization inhibitor and has recently been withdrawn. Packed RBC transfusions are supportive; prevent stroke and manage anemia but are not curative.
